ca.uqac.lif.cep

Class Connector

  • java.lang.Object
    • ca.uqac.lif.cep.Connector

  • public class Connector
extends Object
    Provides a number of convenient methods for connecting the outputs of processors to the inputs of other processors.

    Methods provided by the Connector class are called connect() and have various signatures. Their return value typically consists of the last processor of the chain given as an argument. This means that nested calls to connect() are possible to form a complex chain of processors in one pass, e.g. 

     Processor p = Connector.connect(
   new QueueSource(2, 1),
   Connector.connect(new QueueSource(1, 1), new Addition(), 0, 0),
   0, 1);

    In the previous example, the inner call to connect() links output 0 of a QueueSource to input 0 of an Addition processor; this partially-connected Addition is the return value of this method. It is then used in the outer call, where another QueueSource is linked to its input 1. This fully-connected Addition is what is put into variable p.

    If you use lots of calls to Connector.connect, you may consider writing: 

     static import Connector.connect;
    in the beginning of your file, so you can simply write connect instead of Connector.connect every time.
    Author:
    sylvain

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  Connector.ConnectorException
      Exception thrown when a problem occurs when connecting two processors
      static class  Connector.IncompatibleTypesException
      Exception thrown when two processors with incompatible input/output types are attempted to be connected
      static class  Connector.IndexOutOfBoundsException
      Exception thrown when the connector is asked to pipe something to a nonexistent input or output
      static class  Connector.Variant
      Empty class representing the fact that the output type of a processor may vary

      static boolean s_checkForBounds
      Whether the connector checks that the processors are connected using in/out indexes within the bounds of their arity

      Whether the connector checks that the input-output types of the processor it connects are compatible.

    • Method Detail

      • connect

        public static Processor connect(Processor p1,
                Processor p2,
                int i,
                int j)
                         throws Connector.ConnectorException
        Connects the i-th output of p1 to the j-th input of p2
        Parameters:
        p1 - The first processor
        p2 - The second processor
        i - The output number of the first processor
        j - The input number of the second processor
        Returns:
        A reference to processor p2
        Throws:
        Connector.ConnectorException - If the input/output types of the processors to connect are incompatible

      • connectFork

        public static Processor connectFork(Processor p1,
                    Processor p2,
                    Processor p3)
                             throws Connector.ConnectorException
        Connects three processors, by associating the (first) output of p1 and p2 respectively to the first and second input of p3
        Parameters:
        p1 - The first processor
        p2 - The second processor
        p3 - The third processor
        Returns:
        A reference to processor p3
        Throws:
        Connector.ConnectorException - If the input/output types of the processors to connect are incompatible

      • connect

        public static Processor connect(Processor... procs)
                         throws Connector.ConnectorException
        Connects a chain of processors, by associating the outputs of one to the inputs of the next. The output arity of the first must match that input arity of the next one. In the case the arity is greater than 1, the i-th output is linked to the i-th input.
        Parameters:
        procs - The list of processors
        Returns:
        The last processor of the chain
        Throws:
        Connector.ConnectorException - If the input/output types of the processors to connect are incompatible

      • isCompatible

        public static boolean isCompatible(Processor p1,
                   Processor p2,
                   int i,
                   int j)
                            throws Connector.ConnectorException
        Checks if the i-th output of processor p1 has a declared type compatible with the j-th input of processor p2
        Parameters:
        p1 - The first processor
        p2 - The second processor
        i - The index of the output on the first processor
        j - The index of the input on the second processor
        Returns:
        true if the types are compatible, false otherwise
        Throws:
        Connector.ConnectorException

      • checkForException

        protected static void checkForException(Processor p1,
                     Processor p2,
                     int i,
                     int j)
                                 throws Connector.ConnectorException
        Checks if the i-th output of processor p1 has a declared type compatible with the j-th input of processor p2, and throws an appropriate exception if not
        Parameters:
        p1 - The first processor
        p2 - The second processor
        i - The index of the output on the first processor
        j - The index of the input on the second processor
        Throws:
        Connector.ConnectorException - An exception describing why the connection cannot be mande
